Barrett\u2019s Esophagus_1:
Patient Description 1:
A 56-year-old male patient, with a history of chronic heartburn dating back more than a decade, presented with a new onset of increased intensity in his symptoms. He described a persistent, burning sensation (rated at 7/10 in intensity) behind the sternum, often accompanied by the regurgitation of acidic fluid into his throat. Upper endoscopy revealed the extension of salmon-colored mucosa into the tubular esophagus, reaching 1.5 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. The patient's lifestyle includes regular consumption of spicy foods and a past medical history significant for long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
Barrett\u2019s Esophagus_2:
Patient Description 2:
A 46-year-old female patient, with multiple risk factors for gastroesophageal reflux, including obesity and a history of smoking, reported chronic symptoms of heartburn and acid regurgitation for over six years. She described her daily heartburn as a dull, aching pain (rated at 5/10), which often worsened after consuming fatty meals. Upper endoscopy revealed the presence of salmon-colored mucosa extending 1.2 cm into the tubular esophagus, proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. The patient's lifestyle is characterized by a high-fat diet, and she has a family history of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
Barrett\u2019s Esophagus_3:
Patient Description 3:
A 60-year-old male patient, with a long history of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, presented with recurrent episodes of heartburn and acid regurgitation, which he has been experiencing for more than a decade. He described his typical heartburn pain as sharp and burning, with an intensity ranging from 6 to 8/10. Despite being on proton pump inhibitor therapy for several years, his symptoms persist. Upper endoscopy revealed an extension of salmon-colored mucosa reaching 1.8 cm into the tubular esophagus, proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. The patient has a history of heavy alcohol consumption and is overweight, adding to his risk factors for Barrett's esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma.
